title: Hwange Endline Evaluation
text:
0.1 Programme context
This analysis summarises the Hwange Mobilised Communities (MC) Programme endline evaluation — World Bicycle Relief’s first integrated bicycle mobility pilot for adults, implemented from 2020 to 2025 across 17 rural wards in Hwange District, Zimbabwe. The programme distributed 6,461 Buffalo Bicycles to students, community health workers, conservation volunteers, and livelihood groups to reduce travel barriers to education, healthcare, economic activity, and environmental protection.
Theory of change: If individuals and communities experiencing mobility poverty gain sustained access to appropriate bicycle mobility, and if this access is supported by local governance, maintenance systems, trained mechanics, and spare-parts availability, then they can reduce travel time, physical effort, and travel-related risk, enabling more consistent participation in education, livelihoods, service delivery, and environmental action.

title: Hwange Endline Evaluation
text:
0.2 Headline findings


Retention & durability

98.5% of adult participants retained their bicycles after 4–5 years
77% of bicycles in good condition; high-intensity use (75.5% several times per week)



Education

71.7% reduction in annual absenteeism (12.6 to 3.6 days, 2019–2024)
11.99 pp increase in average academic scores (38.2% to 50.2%)
~6 pp increase per year of bicycle exposure (regression)



Livelihoods

113% increase in households operating a business (20.5% to 43.2%)
98.9% reduction in mean weekly transport cost ($14.40 to $0.20)



Service delivery

24 recipients per week reached on average by mobile community workers
Bicycles used as rural ambulance (46% transported sick family to clinic)

title: 2  Methodology
text:
2.1 Scope and design
The endline evaluation used a non-experimental, mixed-methods design combining:

title: 2  Methodology
text:
Quantitative surveys — Baseline (2020/2021), assessments (2022/2023), endline (2025); adult cohorts and student panel
Student-level administrative records — Fixed panel of 346 unique students, 2019–2024; attendance, academic performance, retention
EMIS data — School-level pass rates and enrolment (project vs non-project schools)
Qualitative data — FGDs and KIIs with participants, mechanics, school leaders, implementing partners

title: 2  Methodology
text:
2.4 Analytical approach

Categorical variables: Chi-square tests (Monte Carlo for sparse tables); significance * p<0.1, ** p<0.05
Continuous variables: Two-sample t-tests; paired t-tests for within-subject; effect sizes reported
Regression: Association between years of bicycle exposure and academic performance (student-level)
Qualitative: Thematic analysis; illustrative quotes tagged by domain and participant type

title: 3  Bicycle Ecosystem
text:
3.1 Ownership and usage
Adult survey data (Wave 4) show 98.5% retention and high-intensity use: 75.5% of adults use the bicycle several times per week. Bicycles are used for travel to market, employment, farming, and domestic tasks; gendered patterns show men more likely to use for formal employment travel and women for informal income-generating activities.

title: 3  Bicycle Ecosystem
text:
3.3 Qualitative insight: care and durability

“Mine is still intact, I keep it like a little baby… or an egg.”
Women’s Group FGD
“If it gets adequate service, it works. I learnt one lesson during my mechanical training. My instructor told me that with proper service, one can use the Buffalo Bicycle for 15 years.”
Mechanic KII

title: 3  Bicycle Ecosystem
text:
3.4 Ecosystem challenges
Maintenance systems function but rely heavily on household contributions. Key challenges include mechanic sustainability (low compensation), spare-parts scarcity, and affordability for the poorest households — see Sustainability.

title: 4  Education Outcomes
text:
4.3 Student voice

“I managed to complete my school just because of the bicycle. The bicycle made us to be at school always… If I had no bicycle, it would be easy for me to hide in the bushes and abscond lessons.”
Out-of-School Alumni FGD
“I used to take two hours walking to school… now the same distance takes only 45 minutes.”
Student FGD
“The fatigue of walking 14 kilometres every day made some students miss lessons… because of the bicycles, they are not missing out.”
School Head KII

title: 4  Education Outcomes
text:
4.4 Retention
Active enrolment remained above 90% despite economic pressures in 2022–2023; 5.8% of the panel dropped out at least once over the six years, with school fees the primary recorded reason. Bicycles appear to have protected retention against distance-related dropout while fee-related barriers persisted.

title: 5  Livelihoods and Household Conditions
text:
5.1 Enterprise and transport costs
The proportion of households operating a business more than doubled from 20.5% (2021) to 43.2% (2025). Mean weekly transport expenditure fell from $14.40 to $0.20 — effectively eliminating transport costs and freeing “virtual income” for school fees, food security, and assets.

title: 5  Livelihoods and Household Conditions
section: 5.2 Qualitative insight: cost reduction and growth
text:
5.2 Qualitative insight: cost reduction and growth

“For me, the biggest change I have noticed in business is the reduction of costs. I no longer pay money for taxis… The growth of my business have resulted in my personal growth.”
FGD Women’s Groups, ISALs Savings and Livelihood
Participants described carrying capacity as central — moving produce, firewood, and goods that were previously head-loaded; access to more distant or multiple markets increased.

title: 5  Livelihoods and Household Conditions
text:
5.3 Gendered impacts
Women reported more control over their time and daily choices; time saved was used for rest, housework, and earning. The programme expanded women’s mobility and agency, though affordability constraints limited who could sustain gains (see Sustainability).

title: 6  Community Service Work
text:
6.1 Service reach
Mobile community workers (health, environmental, administrative) reached an average of 24 recipients per week. Bicycles enabled multi-village coverage within a single day compared to walking, improving meeting attendance and punctuality.

title: 6  Community Service Work
text:
6.2 Emergency response
The bicycle effectively functions as a rural ambulance. In the endline survey, 46% of adult owners reported using the bicycle to transport sick family members to clinics, reducing travel time during emergencies.

title: 6  Community Service Work
text:
6.3 Qualitative context
Service providers and volunteers reported that bicycles strengthened their ability to cover dispersed communities and respond to emergencies, supporting both routine service delivery and crisis response in a human–wildlife conflict context.

title: 7  Sustainability and the Bicycle Ecosystem
text:
7.1 Mechanic sustainability
The maintenance ecosystem shows signs of strain. Mechanics receive limited compensation (e.g. a share of the service fee), which many described as insufficient to sustain livelihoods — contributing to attrition as trained mechanics leave for other work.
crumbs: 7  Sustainability and the Bicycle Ecosystem

title: 7  Sustainability and the Bicycle Ecosystem
text:
“The most foreseen challenge is the mechanics’ sustainability because one cannot wait for thirty cents per bicycle for the whole day serving ten people… it does not sustain him.”
Councillor KII
crumbs: 7  Sustainability and the Bicycle Ecosystem

title: 7  Sustainability and the Bicycle Ecosystem
text:
7.2 Spare parts and affordability
12.8% of respondents cited scarcity of Buffalo-specific parts; 8.7% cited high cost. When official supply lines are delayed, informal sellers inflate prices. The poorest households struggle to pay periodic maintenance (~$3.70), creating a risk that bicycles will break down and stay broken for the most vulnerable.
crumbs: 7  Sustainability and the Bicycle Ecosystem

title: 7  Sustainability and the Bicycle Ecosystem
text:
7.3 Ageing fleet
Cohort 2020 bicycles (older) showed lower reported condition and higher repair costs than Cohort 2021. Preventive maintenance helps but cannot fully offset wear; long-term sustainability depends on stabilising the repair ecosystem — viable mechanic incentives, reliable spare-parts supply, and solutions for major failures.
crumbs: 7  Sustainability and the Bicycle Ecosystem

title: 7  Sustainability and the Bicycle Ecosystem
text:
7.4 Lessons for design

Clear ownership rules mattered more than ownership type; conflict arose when expectations changed after distribution.
Cost-sharing models required adaptation; extreme poverty limited uptake of incentivised sales, prompting a shift toward predominantly donated bicycles for livelihood participants.
Sustainability depends on systems, not bicycle durability alone — weak maintenance financing and mechanic attrition increase breakdown risk over time.
crumbs: 7  Sustainability and the Bicycle Ecosystem

title: 8  Recommendations
text: 8.1 Key recommendations

title: 8  Recommendations
text:
Set ownership arrangements early and apply them consistently — Avoid mid-programme shifts that create confusion or conflict.
Manage bicycles as formal school assets — Record in school registers; link return of functional bicycles to end-of-cycle clearance.
Strengthen maintenance financing and spare-parts access — Ring-fenced maintenance funds or targeted support for poorer households to sustain functionality.
Support mechanics to earn reliable income — Link training to viable repair businesses; ensure local spare-parts access.
Use vulnerability-based targeting alongside gender — Combine gender, distance, poverty, and disability for fair allocation (e.g. where boys face similar distance and poverty as girls).
Build basic maintenance skills among users — Scale the Buffalo Academy–type model to train students and parents in simple preventive maintenance.
Expand access for younger learners — Smaller or adjustable bicycles to address early-stage safety and attendance risks.

title: 8  Recommendations
text:
8.2 Theory of change revisited
The evaluation supports the programme’s theory of change: mobility poverty was a binding constraint, and bicycle access supported by local systems generated durable gains in education, livelihoods, and service delivery. Impacts persist where the bicycle ecosystem remains functional; without system reinforcement, gains will erode unevenly over time. The Hwange MC Programme shows that mobility is a system enabler whose impact depends on how it is governed, financed, and maintained.
